question: He rides a bike.
answer: Il fait du vélo.; Use FAIRE + DE.; Le vélo is masculine singular. de + le = du.

question: I dance.
answer: Je fais de la danse; Use FAIRE + DE.; La danse is feminine singular.

question: to do gymnastics

question: I go to the gym.
answer: Je vais à la salle du sport.

question: to listen to the music

question: to watch television

question: How does acheter change as it is conjugated au présent?
answer: j'achète + tu achètes + il achète + nous achetons + vous achetez + ils achètent; acheter is an -ER verb so the minor variations (adding accent grave è) do not impact the nous and vous forms.

question: How does préférer change as it is conjugated au présent?
answer: je préfère + tu préfères + il préfère + nous préférons + vous préférez + ils préfèrent; préférer is an -ER verb so the minor variations (changing accent aigu to accent grave) do not impact the nous and vous forms.

question: to return something (e.g. clothes to a store)

question: to return / to go back / to come back (when a person - not a thing - is returning)
answer: There are two verbs to choose from. 1) Revenir (RE + VENIR) is like 'come back' to a location that is the same as where the speaker is currently located.; 2) Rentrer means 'to go back home' wherever home is.

question: to break
answer: casser

question: to live/stay at
answer: habiter; rester can be used for staying someplace

question: to dine
answer: dîner

question: to travel
answer: voyager

question: to go hiking
answer: randonner

question: We picnic.
answer: On pique-nique. OR On fait un pique-nique. Pique-nique can be a noun or a verb.

question: to go shopping (for luxury clothing or goods)

question: to go shopping (for daily food + home goods/furniture + clothing + gifts)

question: to think

question: I haven't seen/heard of that (before).

question: to become

question: to immerse (oneself) in something

answer: Tu t'immerge DANS français.; The masculine version of a nationality is the short form for the language.

question: to take (an exam) / to retake (an exam)

question: My grades are bad.

answer: Ça arrive. OR Ça se passe.; ARRIVER is typically used for both 'to arrive' and 'to happen'.; You can also use the verb SE PASSER for 'to happen'.

question: Two things happened.
answer: Deux choses sont arrivées. OR Deux choses se sont passées.

question: to talk / to speak
answer: parler

question: to say (something); Conjugate it.

question: to cry/weep
answer: pleurer

question: to shout
answer: crier

question: to sing
answer: chanter

answer: commencer + arrêter

question: to dance
answer: danser

question: to memorize
answer: mémoriser

question: to cost
answer: coûter

question: to spend (money) + to pay
answer: dépenser + payer ('pay-yay'... two Y sounds)

question: conjugate payer (to pay) au présent
answer: je paye/paie + tu payes/paies + il paye/paie + nous payons + vous payez + ils payent/paient; Payer is a -YER verb so for all forms (except nous and vous) the Y can stay or it can be changed to I. Both forms are correct.

question: List 5 verbs ending in -YER and explain what is special about their conjugation.
answer: payer (to pay) + essayer (to try) + nettoyer (to clean) + envoyer (to send) + effrayer (to frighten) + s'ennuyer (to be bored); -YER verbs can be conjugated in two ways au présent that are totally correct... for all forms (except nous and vous) the Y can stay or it can be changed to I.

question: to leave (a tip + a message + etc)
answer: laisser

question: the tip
answer: le pourboire; literally 'for a drink'

question: a tip/trick (for doing something fast/well)
answer: une astuce

question: to grab a drink (like with a friend)
answer: prendre un verre

question: to go too far / to cross the line
answer: dépasser les bornes; This is a french expression.

question: a favor
answer: une faveur

question: to invite (also means to host - you will pay for the person you invite)
answer: inviter

question: to share (also to split a bill)
answer: parteger; On partage? = shall we split it?

question: to give + to give back
answer: donner + redonner

question: to read

answer: écrire + épeler + inscrire

question: to take + to learn + to understand
answer: prendre + apprendre + comprendre; see how they are all related!

question: How does the pronunciation of 'en' change when we conjugate of comprendre?
answer: je/tu comprends + il comprend etc...the EN sounds as expected in french like 'uhn'. But ils comprennent... The double N changes how the E sounds. So ENN sounds like 'ehn'.; NB: This rule works for all words including the conjugations of similar verbs like prendre and apprendre.

question: to learn to do something (e.g. to learn to dance)

question: to study + to organize
answer: étudier + organiser

answer: mémoriser OR apprendre par cœur (to learn by heart)

question: to plan
answer: prévoir; NB: The noun for 'the plan' is le plan.

answer: J'essaie une robe.; ESSAYER alone if followed by some noun that you are trying (on).

question: May I try on this dress? (at a store)
answer: Est-ce que je pourrais essayer la veste?; In a store always use the polite forms (e.g. use pouvoir and/or conditionnel tense)

question: I will think on it. (at a store)
answer: Je vais réfléchir.;RÉFLÉCHIR means to think but it can be used reflexively to mean to reflect (SE RÉFLÉCHIR)

question: to listen to + to hear (two different verbs)
answer: écouter / entendre (past participle: entendu); NB: entendre can be used to mean 'I hear you' as in 'I get you'

question: I do not hear the verb.
answer: Je n'entends pas le verbe.; NB: verbe is masculine even though ends in vowel

question: to express
answer: exprimer; s'exprimer is to express oneself

question: to describe
answer: décrire

question: to tell (a story)
answer: racontrer (une histoire); This verb is used much more commonly than dire (to say) when you are talking about something that is said.

question: I take notes.

question: to close + to lock out
answer: fermer + enfermer; e.g. J'ai enfermé mon ami al exterior. = I locked my friend outside.

answer: goûter

question: I drink water.
answer: Je bois de l'eau.; I do not know why DE is required in this case but this is definitely how we express it.

question: I eat. / I am eating.
answer: Je mange. / Je suis en train de manger.; To use gerund in the present tense: conjugated être + en train de + infinitive of the verb.

question: I learn. I am learning.
answer: J'apprends. / Je en train d'apprendre.; To use gerund in the present tense: conjugated être + en train de + infinitive of the verb.

question: to teach / teaching
answer: enseigner / l'enseignement

answer: Tu m'as enseigné ça.

question: to travel (to some city)

question: to visit

question: to feel

answer: Ça me fait du bien.

answer: Elle ressemble à Jane.; When you are saying that two things (people + cities + anything) look similarly then use RESSEMBLER + À instead of AVOIR L'AIR.

question: to seem (like something)
answer: The literal translation is the verb SEMBLER (think about 'ensemble' = together). But often in french we use AVOIR + L'AIRE + X to express this sentiment - it is literally 'to have he air of something'.; Alternatively you can use TROUVER (to find). e.g. Je le trouve X. = I find it (to be) X.

question: They seemed nice.
answer: Ils avaient l'air gentils.; Use imparfait because you are describing a scene or telling a story.

question: She looks/sounds/seems sad.

answer: Typically we use AVOIR + L'AIRE + X to express this.; Il a l'air bête/marrant. = It sounds funny/silly/odd. (bête means stupid but it is used in a light-hearted way here); Alternatively you can use: trouver amusant(e) which loosely means to find it fun or funny. Je le trouve amusante. = I find it funny.

question: I walk a lot. / I am walking.
answer: Je marche beaucoup. / Je suis en train de marcher.

question: to go for a walk / to take a stroll
answer: se promener / se balader OR faire une promenade; So you can say: Je me promène. OR Je fais une promenade.

question: to run
answer: courir (past participle: couru); to go for a run: faire du jogging

question: My children go swimming in the pool.
answer: Mes enfants font de la natation dans la piscine.

answer: réduire (la vitesse)

answer: suvivre

answer: faire preuve

question: to bother (like to annoy)
answer: déranger

question: to gain weight / to lose weight
answer: grossir / maigrir; prendre du poids is another common say to express gaining weight in an unplanned way; prendre du muscle is how you say putting on weight/muscle on purpose

question: to be in good shape
answer: être en forme

question: Cake makes one gain weight.
answer: Le gâteau fait grossir.

question: a diet
answer: un régime

question: to take a class
answer: There are many ways to express this.; 1) Use suivre (to follow): Je suis (same conjugation and pronunciation as être) un cours de français.; 2) Use prendre (to take/make): Je prends un cours de tango.

question: to follow (a person + a diet + a course of study)

question: to volunteer
answer: faire du bénévolat; He/She is a volunteer. =  Il/Elle est bénévole.

question: to do good
answer: faire du bien; This means to contribute something good (like volunteering). It does NOT mean to do well at just any kind of activity.

question: to open
answer: ouvrir

question: to reschedule
answer: changer la date; changer = to change; un changement = the change

question: to improve

question: to heal / treat

question: to abuse / mistreat

question: I am going to be treated.

question: to dial a phone number

answer: décrocher / racrocher

answer: modifier

answer: ajouter

answer: mélanger

answer: eplucher

answer: faire cuir

answer: faire griller

answer: faire frire

question: to sautee
answer: faire sauter; the literal translation is to jump

question: to serve (conjugate)
answer: servir; je sers ('sehr') + tu sers ('sehr') + il sert ('sehr') + nous servons ('sehr-von') + vous servez ('sehr-vay') + ils servent ('sehrv')

answer: amener + ramener

question: to wear / to carry; I am wearing a red scarf.
answer: porter; Je porte une écharpe rouge.

question: You are carrying the baggage.
answer: Tu portes les bagages.

question: conjugate the verb 'to put on'

question: I am putting on a dark green sweater.
answer: Je mets ('may') un pull vert foncé.

question: conjugate the verb 'to continue' (doing something)
answer: laisser ('le-say') - S sound because double s; je laisse ('les') + tu laisses + il laisse + nous Laissons + vous laissez ('le-say')+ ils laissent ('les')

question: (you formal) Continue cooking the meat.
answer: Laissez la viande.

question: to be hurt
answer: avoir mal

question: to offer
answer: offrir

question: to leave
answer: partir

question: I left for Paris to study.
answer: Je suis parti à Paris pour ètudier.; Use à to indicate where you left to; Use de to indicate whree you left from; suis parti is passé composé

question: to go out

answer: fêter; On a fêté.

question: I would like to find...

question: We go to a concert.
answer: On va au concert. OR On voit un concert = We see a concert. Verb is voir.

question: to see a band
answer: voir un groupe de musique

question: to see eachother
answer: se voir; Make the verb VOIR reflexive.

question: to pack / unpack (when moving to a new place)

question: to pack (for a vacation) + I packed (for holidays)

answer: J'espère

question: to be called something / to call out

question: conjugate 'to be called'
answer: It's reflexive: se appeler; remember that an extra 'L' is added in some of the forms; je m'appelle ('juh-ma-pel') + tu t'appelles ('too-ta-pel') + il/elle/on s'appelle ('el-sah-pel') + nous nous appelons ('nu-nu-zapluh') + vous vous appelez ('vu-vu-zah-play')+ ils/elles s'appellent ('el-sah-pel'); NB: Use s' when working with ON because same conjugation as il/elle.; NB: Only the nous and vous forms have a single L and have a different pronunciation.; NB: There are apostrophes when the pronoun (e.g. me/te/se) ends in a vowel because the verb starts with a vowel and we cannot have two vowels next to eachother.

question: Your name is X.

question: I call you X.

question: I call (on the telephone).
answer: J'appelle.; uses the NON-reflexive form of the verb: appeler

question: reflexive verbs
answer: verbes pronominaux; because a pronoun is part of the verb

question: What is the name for the pronoun used in reflexive verbs (e.g. me)
answer: le pronom réfléchi

question: What must be true if you see the word 'se' written in french?
answer: This is only written when using a reflexive verb. You know that whatever word follows 'se' is a reflexive verb.

question: to sit down + I sit down.
answer: s'asseoir ('sa-swar') + Je m'assois.; Generally this verb is reflexive because you need to specify what is being sat down.

question: We sit down. We sat down.
answer: Nous nous assoyons. Nous nous sommes assis.; s'asseoir is reflexive so it uses être in passé composé.; We are describing a discrete action (potentially a conclusion to a story) so we use passé composé instead of imparfait.

question: I was sitting. We were sitting.
answer: J'assoyais. Nous étions assis.; In this case we are describing a setting in the past using imparfait. The sitting down action was already completed so we are not describing an action. Therefore we do not need to use the reflexive form.

question: to find + to discover

question: to lose

question: to forget / overlook; conjugate and give pronunciation

question: to miss

question: to try (someone or something) ...to give it a chance

question: to trust

question: to distrust
answer: ne faire pas confiance à OR se méfier ('may-fee-yay'); SE MÉFIER sounds different than fier/fiére ('fyehr') - which is the word for proud.

question: to wash / to wash oneself
answer: laver / se laver

question: to take a shower
answer: se doucher (reflexive)

question: I do not take a shower.
answer: Je NE me douche PAS.;NB: For reflexive verbs the NE comes before both the verb and the associated pronoun. Like non-reflexive verbs the PAS comes after the verb when using a reflexive verb.

question: to shave

question: to get up (in the morning)

question: She gets up in the morning.

question: to get dressed

question: to brush (hair or teeth)

question: I slept in.

question: What time did you wake up?

question: to relax

question: I relaxed.

question: I remember it.; What is the infinitive of the verb?
answer: Je m'en souviens. (juh-muh-soo-vyuh); SE SOUVENIR (to remember) is the verb and it is reflexive - which is where the me/m' comes from.; This is the most common way to express this idea... 'en' is used in special cases to represent 'it' - french people do NOT say: Je me le souviens.

question: I don't remember it.

question: I don't remember the conjugation.

question: I don't remember everything.

question: What do you remember?

question: You remember it. Do you remember it?

question: It helps me to remember.

question: a memory
answer: un souvenir

question: to replace / Replace X with Y.
answer: replacer / Replacez X par Y.; The formal you (vous) is understood/omitted in the command.

question: How do you contruct a command (impératif aka imperative)?
answer: There are three possibilities: tu + nous + vous. The subject is assumed so you omit the subject entirely. Then use the present tense conjugation of the verb. For regular -ER verbs: remove the S from the tu form.; e.g. Eat the food.: (tu) Mange / (nous) Mangeons / (vous) Mangez la nourriture.

question: (you informal) Cut the bread.
answer: Coupe le pain.; couper is a regular -er verb so we use the present tense conjugation for tu (coupes) and then remove the S.

question: (we / let's) Change the sheets.
answer: Changeons les draps.; changer is the verb - the present tense conjugation for nous is changeons.

question: (you formal) Listen.
answer: écoutez.; écouter is the verb - the present tense conjugation for vous is écoutez.

question: How do you construct a command (impératif) for group 2 (-ir) verbs?
answer: Keep the final S in the tu form.; e.g. Finish the food.: (tu) Finis / (nous) Finissons / (vous) Finissez la nourriture.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Go to the store.
answer: (tu) Va / (nous) Allons / (vous) Allez au magasin.; Aller is treated as a regular -ER verb in this case so we remove the S from the conjugated tu form.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Cook the meat.
answer: (tu) Fais cuire / (nous) Faisons / (vous) Faites le viande.; Faire is an irregular verb so we do not delete the S at the end of the tu verb form!

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Be nice.
answer: (tu) Sois / (nous) Soyons / (vous) Soyez sympa.; être is a fully irregular verb for imperative - you have to memorize the three.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Get a cat.
answer: Use the verb avoir (to have): (tu) Aie / (nous) Ayons / (vous) Ayez un chat.; avoir is a completely irregular verb for imperative - you have to memorize the three.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Put on the coat.
answer: Use the verb mettre (to put): (tu) Mets / (nous) Mettons / (vous) Mettez le manteau.; keep the S on the tu form because mettre is irregular in the imperative case

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Do something.
answer: Use the verb faire: (tu) Fais / (nous) Faisons / (vous) Faites quelque chose.; keep the S on the tu form because faire is irregular in the imperative case

question: How do you construct a command (impératif) for reflexive verbs?
answer: The pronoun gets attached to the end of the verb.; e.g. (you informal) Go for a walk! = Promène-toi!; SE PROMENER is an -er verb so the S is omitted in the you informal form.

question: Let's go for a walk!
answer: (nous) Promenons-nous!; Use the impératif command form. SE PROMENER is the verb. To make the impératif for a reflexive verb attach the pronoun after the verb.

question: (you informal) Hurry up!
answer: Dépêche-toi!

question: (you formal) Register! / Sign up!
answer: (vous) Inscrivez-vous!; Use the impératif command form. S'INSCRIRE is the verb. To make the impératif for a reflexive verb attach the pronoun after the verb.

question: (you formal) Do not eat that!
answer: (vous) Ne mangez pas ça!; Use the impératif command form. Mangez ça! would be the positive form. To negate it: NE comes directly after where the subject should be. PAS comes directly following the verb.

question: (formal / informal) Drink lots of water.

question: (formal / informal) Always sleep for 8 hours.

question: (formal / informal) Take some medicine.
answer: Prends / Prenez des médicaments.

question: (formal / informal) Put a wet towel on your forehead.
answer: Mets / Mettez une serviette de toillette humide sur ton / votre front.

question: How do you construct the near future tense in French (le futur proche)?
answer: ALLER conjugated + INFINITIVE of the verb you are going to do; The direct translation is 'X is going to do something'. NB: All object pronouns are placed between the two verbs!

question: When do you use futur proche?
answer: Technically it should only be used for something that will happen imminently or a change to the status quo. Those are the only ways that you should use futur proche in writing. If something will occur further into the future in writing then use futur simple instead.; But when speaking it is very common for people to use futur proche for anything in the future because it's easy to formulate. It is especially correct to say something like: Le année prochaine je vais aller... because you made the time frame clear.

question: I am going to go (for a) walk. Use futur proche.
answer: Je vais marcher.

question: They are going to eat. Use futur proche.
answer: Ils vont manger.

question: After we go to the cinema we will drink a glass. Use futur proche.
answer: Aprés on va au cinema on va boire une verre.

question: You are going to eat it (masculine). Use future proche.
answer: Tu va le manger.; Notice how the object pronoun is placed in between the two verbs in future proche.

question: I am going to help you. Use futur proche.
answer: Je vais t'aider.; Notice how the object pronoun is placed in between the two verbs in future proche.; The pronoun te ends in a vowel and the infinitive starts with a vowel so we condense them using apostrophe.

question: How do you construct the simple future tense in French (le futur simple)?
answer: ENTIRE INFINITIVE* + ending that agrees with subject (je –ai + tu -as + il/elle/on -a + nous -ons + vous -ez+ ils/elles -ont); *except for 3rd group and irregular verbs

question: What is the futur simple base for -ER verbs (group 1) and -IR verbs (group 2)?
answer: the entire infinitive for both group 1 and group 2 verbs; e.g. parler and choisir; NB: This is the same base used for the conditionnel tense.

question: What is the futur simple base for group 3 verbs ending in -RE (e.g. prendre + dire + croire + descendre)?
answer: the entire infinitive minus the final E; prendre:prendr + dire:dir + croire:croir + descendre:descendr; NB: This is the same base used for the conditionnel tense.

question: What are the futur simple bases for these irregular verbs: être + aller + faire + venir?
answer: être:ser + aller:ir + faire:fer + venir:viendr; NB: These are the same bases used for the conditionnel tense.

question: What are the futur simple bases for these irregular verbs: avoir + savoir + voir?
answer: avoir:aur + savoir:saur (savoir is conjugated the same as avoir but with an S at the beginning) + voir:verr (voir is totally different than avoir and savoir); NB: These are the same bases used for the conditionnel tense.

question: What are the futur simple bases for these irregular verbs: pouvoir + vouloir + devoir + falloir?
answer: pouvoir:pourr + vouloir:voudr + devoir:devr + falloir:faudr; NB: These are the same bases used for the conditionnel tense.

question: When should you use futur simple?
answer: Generally you should use futur simple when there is certainty that something will happen in the future especially if it is not in the immediate future.; Examples of when to use futur simple: an ongoing change + the result/consequence of a change + plans for the future; Never use futur simple directly following SI (if) because that would be something that is uncertain. - e.g. Si on mange trop (use présant because 'if' makes this part of the sentence uncertain)` alors on grossit (use futur simple because this part of the sentence is a certainty).

question: What verb tense will generally follow these setups: Quand ... + Pendent que ... + J'espére que ...?
answer: Assuming you are describing an event in the future then use futur simple in these phrases.

question: When should you use alors vs puis?
answer: Alors is a good transition word when you are revealing a consequence of the earlier sentence (e.g. if i eat too much then i will gain weight).; Puis is good transition word if you are describing sequential steps (e.g. We went to dinner. Then we went to a movie.)

question: When should you use futur simple vs conditional?
answer: If there is anything about the future statement that is uncertain then use conditional. e.g. If she goes (présent) I would go (conditional WOULD).; If the future statment is certain then use futur simple. e.g. If she goes (présent) I will go (futur simple WILL).

question: I will finish. Use futur simple.
answer: Je finirai. (finir is the infinitive + ai to agree with je)

question: I will finish it (masculine). Use futur simple.
answer: Je le finirai.; All pronouns representing objects of the verb are placed before the verb in futur simple.

question: I have not yet finished.
answer: Je n'ai pas encore fini.

question: You will go out. Use futur simple.
answer: Tu sortiras. (sortir is the infinitive + as to agree with tu)

question: You (plural/formal) will sing. Use futur simple.
answer: Vous chanterez. (chanter is the infinitive + ez to agree with vous)

question: They will arrive tonight. Use futur simple.
answer: Ils arriveront ce soir.

question: I will take. Use futur simple.
answer: Je prendrai.; For verbs that end in -e (like PRENDRE) we remove the -e from the infinitive before applying the same futur simple endings to agree with the subject.; PRENDR + AI

question: They will put. Use futur simple.
answer: Ils mettront.; Follows the same pattern as PRENDRE.; 'muh-tron' because -ont is still pronounced in this form.

question: We will wait. Use futur simple.
answer: On attendra.; Attendre is the infinitive. It ends in -e so subtract the -e. Then add the -a ending for il/elle/on.; ATTENDR + A

question: I will come tomorrow. Use futur simple.
answer: Je viendrai demain.; This is an example of a verb that is irregular in futur simple. The infinitive for 'to come' is VENIR. But we change it to VIENDR and then add the futur simple endings.

question: You will go. Use futur simple.
answer: Tu iras.; Aller is irregular in futur simple. The infinitive for 'to go' is ALLER. But we change it to IR and then add the futur simple endings.

question: I will go. He would go.
answer: J'irai (futur simple). Il irait (conditionnel).; Note that the conditional conjugated forms sounds like the first person futur simple form.

question: We will go shopping / run errands.
answer: Nous ferons des courses.; Faire is irregular in futur simple. Instead of 'fair' we use the base 'fer' and then add the endings.

question: You (formal/plural) will be in Paris.
answer: Vous serez à Paris.; être is irregular in futur simple. We use 'ser' as the base and then add the endings.

question: She will have a cat.
answer: Elle aura un chat.; Avoir is irregular in futur simple. We use 'aur' as the base and then add the endings.

question: What will you eat? (use futur simple)
answer: Que mangeras-tu?

question: What will you (informal) do? / What will you (formal) do?
answer: Que feras-tu? / Que ferez-vous?; Faire is irregular in past participle using 'fer' as base.

question: Where will you (formal) go on vacation?
answer: Où irez-vous en vacances?; Aller is irregular in past participle using 'ir' as base.; vacation is always plural in french - vacances

question: I will see you (informal). Use futur simple.
answer: Je te verrai.

question: I will do it.
answer: Je le ferai.

question: If I save money then I will travel to Italy.
answer: Si j'economise d'argent puis j'irai à l'Italie.; The first phrase is in présent indicatif because it is a hypothesis. The second phrase is in futur simple because it is something that will certainly happen if the hypothesis is met.

question: I will work more if I travel less.
answer: Je traveillerai plus si je voyage moins.; The first phrase is futur simple because it happens in the future if the hypothesis (the second phrase in présent indicatif) is met.

question: Is it possible for the futur simple to follow the word SI (if) directly?
answer: It is possible if the SI indicates 'whether or not something will happen' instead of indicating a hypothesis ('if something happens').;e.g. Je ne sais pas SI je partirai. = I do not know IF (yes/no) I will leave (futur simpl directly follows the SI). Si je pars... = IF I leave... (hypothesis so présent directly follows the SI)

question: I will not eat butter any more. (use futur simple)
answer: Je NE mangerai PLUS de beurre.; 'no more' is a quantity so you have to use the basic DE which does not agree with the noun.; This is one way to express that you will stop doing something in the future.

question: I will not eat butter or bread. (use future simple)
answer: Je NE mangerai PAS de beurre NI de pain.; 'none' is a quantity so you have to use the basic DE which does not agree with the noun.; Use NI instead of ET when you are are negating multiple items.; This is another way to express that you will stop doing something in the future.

question: I will never eat butter. (use future simple)
answer: Je NE mangerai JAMAIS de beurre.; 'none ever' is a quantity so you have to use the basic DE which does not agree with the noun.; This is one way to express that you will stop doing something in the future.

question: I will stop eating butter. (use future simple)
answer: J'arrêterai manger de beurre.; This is another way to express that you will stop doing something in the future.

question: I will stop. (use future simple)
answer: Je m'arrêterai.; When you use arrêter and you do not specify what you are stopping then you must use the reflexive form of the verb (SE ARRÊTER) to explain that you are stopping yourself ...from doing something. You cannot just say: J'arrête.

question: What is the conditionnel tense?
answer: This exists in English (the conditional). It is a future tense that is hypothetical.; e.g. I would / could / should (do something) - there is uncertainty / an implied IF; You would do something IF something else were true but the IF statement is usually implied.; I would do it = Je le ferrais (the verb faire conjugated in the conditionnel); This is the tense we use to be polite.

question: How is the conditionnel tense constructed in French?
answer: Use the same base as the futur simple (the entire infinitive or modified infinitive). Then add the imparfait endings to agree with subject: je -ais + tu -ais + il/elle/on -ait + nous -ions + vous -iez + ils/elles -aient; NB: Futur conditional for almost all the types of subjects (je/tu/il/ils) sounds exactly the same as the first person singular (je) form for futur simple (though spelled differently).; But the nous and vous forms - as expected - are pronounced uniquely.

question: I would like some milk.
answer: Je voudrais du lait.; This is in futur conditionnel tense.

question: How do you express: I could (do something)?
answer: Use POUVOIR and the conditionnel tense.; Je POURRais faire quelques chose.; Pouvoir - to be able to - is conjugated in the conditional. The subsequent verb is in the infinitive.

question: How do you express: I should (do something)?
answer: Use DEVOIR and the conditionnel tense.; Je DEVRais (use futur simple base: devr) faire quelques chose.; Devoir - to must - is conjugated in the conditional. The subsequent verb is in the infinitive.

question: How do you express: I had (to do something)?
answer: Use DEVOIR in the imparfait (past) because telling a story.; Je DEVais (use imparfait base: dev) faire quelques chose.; Devoir - to must - is conjugated in the imparfait. The subsequent verb is in the infinitive.; If you really needed to use passé composé (e.g. if you were stating a conclusion to past activity) then it would be: J'ai du (past participle of devoir) faire quelques chose.

question: How do you express: I didn't need (something)?
answer: Use AVOIR BESOIN in the imparfait (past) because telling a story.; Je n'avais pas besoin quelques chose.; There is no second infinitive verb when you use avoir besoin.

question: I will be able to. (futur simple) / I could. (futur conditionnel)
answer: Je pourrai. / Je pourrais.; Pronounced exactly the same ('pour-ray') because je/tu/il/elle/on/ils/elles in future conditional sound exactly the same as je in futur simple - though spelled differently.; Remember 'ai' sounds like 'ay' in french - like j'ai.

question: I will eat. (futur simple) / They would eat. (future conditionnel)
answer: Je mangerai. / Ils mangeraient.; Pronounced exactly the same ('man-jer-ray') because je/tu/il/elle/on/ils/elles in future conditional sound exactly the same as je in futur simple - though spelled differently.; -ent is always silent on verbs

question: I will have more time. (futur simple) / I will know how to do it. (futur simple)
answer: J'aurai plus de temps. / Je saurai comment faire.; NB: AVOIR and SAVOIR are usually conjugated in the same way - just add an S to the front for the SAVOIR version.

question: It took to long.
answer: Ça pris trop de temps.

question: I quit. / I will quit. / I would quit.
answer: J'ai quitté. / Je quitterai. / Je quitterais.; QUITTER is the infinitive. It also means 'to leave'.

question: Using the verb ÉCOUTER... You would listen. / He would listen.(both future conditionnel)
answer: Tu écouterais. / Il écouterait.; ('ay-coo-tuh-ray') Both sound exactly the same as Je version in futur simple (j'écouterai) - though they are spelled differently.

question: Using the verb CHANTER... They would sing. / You (formal/plural) would sing. (both future conditionnel)
answer: Ils chanteraient. ('shon-tu-ray') / Vous chanteriez. ('shon-tu-ree-ay'); The ils version sounds exactly the same as the je version in futur simple (je chanterai) BUT the vous version sounds different because nous and vous versions do not follow the rule that je/tu/il/elle/on/ils/elles follow.

question: Using the verb VOIR... She would watch. / We (nous) would watch. (both future conditionnel)
answer: Elle verrait. / Nous verrions.; VOIR is irregular in futur simple - we use the base 'verr'.; Notice that the pronunciation rule still holds: Elle verrait (She would watch) sounds the same as Je verrai (I will watch). BUT Nous verrions (We would watch) does not sound the same as Je verrai (I will watch) because nous and vous never follow the pronunciation rule.

question: You (familiar) would go. / You (formal/plural) would go. (both futur conditionnel)
answer: Tu irais. / Vous iriez.; ALLER is irregular in futur simple - we use the base 'ir'.; The pronunciation similarities still hold. Tu irais (You would go) sounds the same as J'irai (I will go). Vous form sounds different - always does.

question: How do you express that something is in the conditionnel tense?
answer: au conditionnel

question: How do you ask politely: Do you have eggs (formal and informal)?
answer: Auriez-vous / Aurais-tu des œufs?; Verb is AVOIR. Use conditionnel to be polite.

question: How do you ask politely: May I keep this?
answer: Pourrais-je garder ça?; Verb is POUVOIR. Use conditionnel to be polite.

question: How do you ask politely: Could you please open the door?
answer: Pourriez-vous / Pourrais-tu ouvrir la porte?; Verb is POUVOIR. Use conditionnel to be polite.

question: How do you ask politely: Would you like some water?
answer: Voudriez-vous / Voudrais-tu de l'eau?; Verb is VOULOIR. Use conditionnel to be polite.

question: for politeness / in order to be polite
answer: par politesse

question: How do you construct the passé composé (a past tense) in French?
answer: AUXILIARY VERB (conjugated form of etre or avoir) + simple PAST PARTICIPLE of the main verb; in English it's like 'i have jumped.'; NB: If étre is the auxiliary (helper) verb then the past participle must also agree with the subject including gender for ALL forms - not just the third person (e.g. il/elle)

question: Generally how do you make the past participle of a verb?
answer: -er verbs: stem + é ...which sounds exactly the same as the 2nd person plural (vous) in present that ends with -ez; -re verbs: stem + -is OR stem + u; -ir verbs: stem + i; -oir verbs: stem + u

question: I ate. We drank.
answer: J'ai mangé. On a bu.; boire is the infinitive for 'to drink' - bu is the past participle and it uses AVOIR in passé composé.

question: You (informal and formal) bought.
answer: Tu as acheté. Vous avez acheté.

question: They studied.
answer: Ils ont étudié.; étudier is the infinitive and it follows the same rules because the stem is 'étudi' - not 'étud'.

question: They did not study. I did not study.
answer: Ils n'ont étudié. Je n'ai pas étudié.

question: All in past tense: I read. / I read it. / I did not read it.
answer: J'ai lu. / Je l'ai lu. / Je ne l'ai pas lu.; Lire changes to Lu for past participle.

question: I learn. / I learned.
answer: J'apprends. ('juh-prawn') / J'ai appris ('jay ah-pree')

question: She waited until I finished.
answer: Ella a attendu que j'ai fini.

question: What is the past participle for to take + to learn + to understand?
answer: prendre -> pris + apprendre -> appris + comprendre -> compris; remember S is silent at the end

question: I took. / I gave.
answer: J'ai pris. (prendre changes to pris for past participle) / J'ai donné.

question: We saw something.
answer: On a vu quelque chose.; Voir is the infinitive. It uses avoir in passé composé and the participle is vu.; NB: The general rule for making a past participle for a verb ending in -OIR is to replace -OIR with -U.

question: We didn't see anything.
answer: On n'a rien vu.; Negation requires two parts. NE (shortened to n' here because followed by a vowel) + RIEN (takes the place of PAS to indicate nothing)

question: They wanted something. (use passé composé)
answer: Ils/Elles ont voulu quelque chose.;Voulour is the infinitive. It uses avoir in passé composé and the participle is voulu.; NB: The general rule for making a past participle for a verb ending in -OIR is to replace -OIR with -U.

question: They wanted me to... (use imparfait)
answer: Ils voulaient que je...

question: You were able (to pay).
answer: Tu a pu (payer).; Pouvoir is the infinitive (to be able to). Pouvoir uses avoir in passé composé and the participle for all subjects is pu.; NB: pouVOIR is the infinitive so it should be conjugated exactly the same as VOIR (to see).

question: Which 5 verbs have a completely irregular past particle?
answer: avoir (eu) + être (été) + faire (fait) + offrir (offert) + ouvrir (ouvert)

question: He had. / He was. / He did (something).
answer: Il a eu. / Il a été. / Il a fait.; All the 5 verbs with an irregular past participle use AVOIR as the auxiliary verb in passé composé.

question: How do you say 'There is...' (il y a...) in the past (there were...) and future (there will be...)?
answer: For past you must use imparfait because it describes the scene (instead of an action): Il y avait... (not Il y a eu...).; For the future use futur simple: Il y aura...

question: I went there.
answer: J'y suis allé(e). - depending on whether the subject is masculine or feminine.; There are only about 16 verbs that use être when constructing the past tense (as opposed to avoir). question: He/She went out.
answer: Il est sorti. / Elle est sortie.; There are only about 16 verbs that use être when constructing the past tense (as opposed to avoir). Sortir is one of the verbs that uses être in past tense - which also means that the participle must agree with the subject.

question: What are some ways of remembering which verbs use être in passé composé (a past tense)?
answer: La maison de être: the 15 verbs typically have to do with position and can be illustrated in and around a house; The following acronym helps us remember the 15 verbs MRS VANDERTRAMPP; Remember that when être is the auxiliary verb then the past participle must agree with the subject.

question: What are the 15 base verbs that use être in passé composé (a past tense)?
answer: Monter Retourner Sortir Venir (e.g. includes devenir + revenir + etc.) Arriver Naître Descendre Entrer Rentrer Tomber Rester Aller Mourir Partir Passer; Remember that when être is the auxiliary verb then the past participle must agree with the subject.

question: Conjugate 'to arrive' in passé composé.
answer: ARRIVER is the infinitive; Je suis arrivé(e) (m/f) + Tu es arrivé(e) (m/f) + Il/Elle/On est arrivé(e) (m/f) + Nous sommes arrivés + Vous êtes arrivés + Ils/Elles sont arrivé(e)s; explanation: arriver uses être in passé composé. question: I leave. / I left (a place).

So if a verb (that normally uses avoir in passé composé) is used reflexively in passé composé then it might be an additional case of an irregular être verb in passé composé.

question: How do you construct passé composé for reflexive verbs?
answer: All reflexive verbs use être as a helper verb (regardless of whether or not they use être in the non-reflexive form). SUBJECT + PRONOUN (me/te/...) + ÊTRE CONJUGATED + PAST PARTICIPLE OF THE VERB; NB: We are using être as the auxiliary verb in these reflexive cases so the past participle must agree with the subject.

answer: NE (as always) comes directly after the subject. PAS goes between the two verbs.; e.g. We did not do X. = Nous n'avons pas fait X.

You must refer to what it is that was told (You told it to me.)- even if you just use a pronoun and even if you already described it in a previous sentence.; It's similar to how you must always use an article before a noun - you can't be implicit with either.;  Both the direct and indirect objects come before the verb.

question: What is the subjonctif (subjunctive) verb tense?
answer: It is used to express something that is desired. e.g. I wish that the whether is nice. - 'I wish' triggers the subjonctif tense to be used in the phrase 'the weather is nice'.; There are a lot of scenarios that trigger the subjonctif. Falloir (e.g. Il faut...) is a common trigger.; Three major categories (not exhaustive) that trigger the subjonctif include: 1) preferences / advice / needs / desires / orders 2) judgements / emotions / feelings 3) possibilities / opinions / doubts / suppositions.

question: What are the requirements of using the subjonctif tense?
answer: Three requirements: 1) A subjonctive phrase is dependent on another phrase triggering the subjonctive tense. e.g. I wish that you have a good life. 'I wish' is présent indicatif but the verb 'to wish' triggers the subjonctive in the subsequent dependent phrase: that you have a good life.; 2) A subjonctive phrase always starts with the word 'que' or 'qui'. e.g. Je souhaite... QUE vous ayez (avoir in subjonctive) une belle vie.; 3) The independent phrase (that triggers the subsequent subjonctif) must have a subject that is different from the subject in the subjonctif phrase. e.g. I wish that I have a good life. You can't use the subjonctif in this case because the subject of both phrases is the same.

question: How do you construct the subjonctif tense?
answer: 1) the base: For je/tue/il/ils forms... use the base from the ils form of the présent indicatif (e.g. venir -> ils viennent -> vienn); For nous/vous forms use the base from the nous form of the présent indicatif (e.g. venir -> nous venons -> ven); 2) the ending: je -e + tu -es + il/elle/on -e + nous -ions + vous -iez + ils/elles -ent

answer: que je parle + que tu parles + qu'il/elle/on parle + que nous parlions + que vous parliez + qu'ils/elles parlent; -ent is silent for all verbs

answer: Elle veut que le soit prêt pour huit heures.; 'She wants...' triggers the subjonctive. And we can use the subjonctive because the subjects of the two phrases (she and the meal) are different.

question: What are pronoms toniques in french?

question: In what scenarios should you use a tonique pronoun?

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) in présent?

So the pronouns are placed before both the auxiliary and past participle.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) in futur proche?
answer: in between the conjugated form of ALLER and the INFINITIVE; NB: This follows the rule of dual verbs. Whenever you need two different verbs in french where one is a conjugated HELPER and the other is the INFINITIVE (e.g. I want to dance = Je veux danser)... then pronouns usually are placed before the infinitive - but not before the helper verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) in futur simple?
answer: If there is only one word representing the verb in futur simple then pronouns come before that verb; NB: This is true for all tenses where a single word represents the entire verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) in conditionnel?
answer: If there is only one word representing the verb in conditionnel then pronouns come before that verb; NB: This is true for all tenses where a single word represents the entire verb.

question: I walk the dog (assume it is a male dog).
answer: Je marche le chein.; Objects of the verb (direct and indirect) come after the verb if they are spelled out/specific (not represented by pronouns).; In this case the dog is a direct object of the verb.

question: I walk it (the male dog). / I walk it (the female dog).
answer: Je le marche./ Je la marche.; A male dog is 'un chien'. A female dog is 'une chienne'.; In this case the dogs are direct objects of the verb. So we use the le/la pronouns.; All object pronouns of the verb (direct and indirect) that are represented by pronouns (not spelled out/specific) are placed before the verb in French!

question: I help him. / I help her.
answer: Je l'aide. Je l'aide.; In this case the person (him/her) is the direct object of the verb. So we use le/la (for direct objects) instead of lui (for indirect objects).; But we have to cut the pronoun to l' (le + aide) to avoid two vowels together.

question: I take you (informal). / I take you (formal).
answer: Je te prends. / Je vous prends.; you is a direct object of the verb in this case so use 'te' and 'vous' pronouns and place them before the verb.

question: I take us.

answer: Je les prends. (same for both); them is a direct object of the verb in this case so use 'les' pronoun to represent the plural things - just like using le/la to represent singular things.

question: You want me to 'do something'.
answer: Tu veux que je... ; 'Me' is NOT an object of the verb in french in this case. The phrase (You want...) triggers the subjunctive and dependent phrase to follow it.

question: They give the cat to me. They give it to me.
answer: Ils/Elles me donnent le chat. Ils/Elles me le donnent ('dun').; NB: 'to X' means that we use the regular indirect object pronouns to represent both words ('to me' becomes 'me'). All pronouns come before the verb. If both direct and indirect objects are represented as pronouns then the indirect object pronoun comes before the direct object pronoun UNLESS both are in the 3rd person - then the direct object pronoun comes before the indirect object pronoun.

question: What is an independent possessive pronoun?
answer: An independent possessive pronoun is a shortcut for showing ownership where the pronoun stands on its own instead of being an adjective to the noun that is possessed. For example: This is my cat. 'my' is a possessive pronoun. 'cat' is the noun being possessed (by me). BUT... This cat is mine. 'mine' is the independent possessive pronoun - you could eliminate the cat entirely: It is mine.

question: What are the independent possessive pronouns in french?
answer: à moi + à toi + à lui + à elle + à nous + à vous + à eux + à elles; These are equivalent to mine/yours/his/hers/ours/you guys'/theirs(m)/theirs(f) in english.; But in french we use à + pronom tonique to express the shortcut in ownership. A rough translation in English would be 'of me/you/her/them'.

question: What is an adverbial pronoun?
answer: It is a pronoun that represents a place or a quantity or the object of a preposition.; 1) there: I go to the store. I go there. There references the store - which also happens to be the object of the preposition 'to'.; 2) them: Cars... I have some of them.; 3) those/that: I have none of this/that.

question: When do you use the pronom Y?
answer: Generally Y replaces a place. It is an adverbial pronoun that stands for 'there'. e.g. la magasin... J'y vais. (I go there.); It is pronounced 'ee' - so J'y is pronounced 'gee'.; But Y can actually replace any structure of à + NOUN. Y can replace any noun in that situation EXCEPT an animate object (which includes people).; If the structure is à + NOUN but the noun is an animate object...then use a tonique pronoun instead.

question: When do you use the pronom EN?
answer: Generally EN replaces something that clearly or vaguely has a count/quantity to it.; Il cherche des idées. (He looks for ideas.)... Il en cherche. (He looks for some.)... J’en ai une. (I have one.);EN can be used in different contexts to replace a NOUN on its own or an entire phrase.

question: When is it difficult to determine when to use Y vs EN?
answer: For example when someone says: I'm thinking about X. And then the next sentence references X as a pronoun. Whether you use EN or Y to reference X depends on whether you say (in french) Je pense à X or Je pense de X. In English we only have one word to express this (think ABOUT it; though sometimes we could use think ON it). So you have to memorize whether to use pense à X or pense de X. Then this determines whether you use Y (replaces à X) or EN (replaces de X).

question: What is 'imparfait' tense? (the imperfect tense within the indicative group)

(imperfect tense within the indicative group); Example: I walked on the beach. (past) / I used to walk on the beach. (the 'imparfait' tense)

question: How do you construct the 'imparfait' tense?

question: What are les relatifs (relative pronouns)
answer: Pronouns that we use to connect phrases that have the same subject. The use of the relative pronoun avoids repetition of the subject. e.g. A hat is on the table. This hat is blue. ...becomes... The hat THAT is on the table is blue. THAT is the relative pronoun. Examples of relative pronouns: that + which + who + + whom + whose + where + when

question: the dress that is interesting + the dress that he loves

La robe QU'IL aime.; Use QUI when the relative pronoun (that) refers to the thing doing the action.; Use QUE when the relative pronoun (that) refers to the thing that is the object of the verb.; Remember QUI never contracts but QUE contracts when followed by a vowel.

question: you (formal) who look at yourself in the mirror

question: the person who you (formal) are watching

So the 'vous' that follows the pronoun is the subject pronoun - the person/thing that is doing the action in the phrase.
